bio: Hubert Auriol led Citroën to a historic trans-African victory, conquering a near 13,000 km odyssey through deserts, jungles, and savannah from Paris to the southern tip of the continent.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1991–92 Paris–Sirte–Cape Town Rally

Date: December 25, 1991 – January 16, 1992

Start Location: Paris, France

Finish Location: Cape Town, South Africa

Total Distance: 12,427 km (6,263 km competitive)

Surface: Gravel, sand, and mixed terrain (marathon rally)

Replacing the canceled 1992 Paris–Dakar, the Paris–Sirte–Cape Town Rally was the most ambitious cross-continental raid of its time. The route crossed nine countries and some of Africa’s harshest terrain, including the Libyan desert, Congolese jungle, and Namibian plains. Hubert Auriol, a former motorcycle and car category champion, added to his legend by guiding the Citroën ZX Rallye Raid across more than 12,000 kilometers of punishing navigation and endurance to take a monumental victory.

🗺️ Route Details

This marathon event covered vastly diverse landscapes across nine African nations:

  • Libya (Sirte and Sahara): Vast dune fields and rocky plateaus tested both navigation skill and cooling systems.
  • Chad and CAR: Remote jungle tracks and dry riverbeds—navigation errors here could cost hours.
  • Congo to Namibia: Alternating between thick vegetation, fesh-fesh dust, and rocky descents—punishing on suspensions.
  • Namib Desert to Cape Town: Wide open stages with extreme heat and high speeds—final push required perfect preservation strategy.

Rainstorms, heat exhaustion, and mechanical failure thinned the ranks, but Citroën’s calculated pace kept them well ahead of trouble throughout the rally.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Hubert Auriol & Philippe Monnet (Citroën ZX Rallye Raid)

2nd Place: Pierre Lartigue & Michel Périn (Citroën ZX Rallye Raid)

3rd Place: Bruno Saby & Jean-Paul Chiaroni (Mitsubishi Pajero Evolution)

Auriol’s win reaffirmed his reputation as a master of marathon rallies—balancing speed with survivability over nearly three weeks of relentless competition.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën ZX Rallye Raid: Lightweight, mid-engined buggy with advanced suspension travel and turbocharged power—ideal for sand and deep ruts.
  • Mitsubishi Pajero Evolution: Heavier, more traditional 4x4 with superior durability in rocky or technical terrain.
  • Nissan Patrol and Toyota Land Cruiser (Privateers): Slower but often more reliable—several made it to Cape Town simply by surviving.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Multi-national Navigation: Route books spanned varied geography, borders, and communication zones—minor missteps were costly.
  • Mechanical Preservation: Suspension damage, electrical faults, and tire fatigue plagued competitors daily—Auriol's team strategy minimized exposure.
  • Health and Endurance: Teams faced dehydration, sleep loss, and illness—mental and physical fatigue were near constant over the three-week journey.

The 1991–92 Paris–Sirte–Cape Town Rally was a modern epic—Hubert Auriol’s victory was one of precision, pacing, and survival over speed alone.

title: 1992 Rallye Monte-Carlo (Monaco)
bio: Didier Auriol opened the 1992 season with a calculated win in the Alps, using sharp tire strategy and experience to outpace rivals in mixed asphalt and snow conditions.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Rallye Monte-Carlo (Monaco)

Date: January 25–29, 1992

Start Location: Valence, France

Finish Location: Monte Carlo, Monaco

Total Distance: 644.20 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt and snow

The 1992 Monte Carlo Rally kicked off the World Rally Championship with treacherous alpine stages and unpredictable winter conditions. Didier Auriol and co-driver Bernard Occelli used superior tire strategy and calm precision to overcome rapidly changing road surfaces. Driving the updated Lancia Delta HF Integrale, Auriol mastered the icy descents and dry tarmac switchbacks, holding off the Toyota and Ford challengers to begin his season with maximum points.

🗺️ Route Details

The route spanned the French Alps before descending toward the Mediterranean coast—providing one of rallying’s most complex tests of grip and concentration:

  • Col de Turini: Iconic night stage with snow patches and tight hairpins—crucial for tire strategy and bravery in the dark.
  • St. Jean-en-Royans and Sisteron: Varied surface grip, with tarmac turning icy around shadowed corners and forested sections.
  • Valberg and Moulinet Loops: High-altitude switchbacks with exposed drop-offs—traction management was everything.

The mix of dry asphalt, slushy snow, and black ice demanded near-psychic tire calls—Auriol and the Lancia team read it better than anyone else on the stages that mattered most.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Didier Auriol & Bernard Occelli (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185)

3rd Place: François Delecour & Dominique Savignoni (Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4)

Auriol’s victory confirmed his mastery of winter rallies and began the year with strong momentum for Lancia’s continuing title campaign.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Refined AWD platform with improved response—tire-friendly and extremely well-balanced for Alpine switchbacks.
  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185: Powerful and steady—Sainz was quick but missed a few key tire gambles.
  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4: Strong on dry tarmac but struggled for grip on slick or icy sections—still managed a competitive podium finish.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Tire Strategy: The defining variable—drivers had to bet on the grip level of multiple zones in a single stage.
  • Changing Elevation: Climbs and descents affected both grip and engine response—perfect throttle control was key.
  • Night Stages: Fatigue and limited visibility raised the difficulty—Col de Turini was again the rally’s make-or-break stretch.

The 1992 Rallye Monte-Carlo reminded everyone why it’s the most unpredictable event on the calendar—Auriol’s calm under pressure earned him a well-deserved win in the mountains of Monaco.

title: 1992 International Swedish Rally (Sweden)
bio: Local hero Mats Jonsson stunned the WRC field with a flawless drive through the snowy forests of Sweden, claiming a popular victory in his Toyota Celica GT-Four ST165.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 International Swedish Rally (Sweden)

Date: February 13–16, 1992

Start Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Finish Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Total Distance: 448.00 km of special stages

Surface: Snow and ice

The 1992 Swedish Rally delivered classic winter rallying—narrow, high-speed forest roads lined with snowbanks and the ever-present risk of getting stuck. Mats Jonsson, competing as a privateer with deep local experience, took full advantage of the conditions and his knowledge of the terrain. With Lars Bäckman beside him, Jonsson piloted his older-spec Toyota Celica GT-Four ST165 to an emotional and unexpected home win against factory-backed titans.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally’s stages traversed Värmland’s frozen forests, demanding absolute confidence in grip, pacenotes, and snowbank usage:

  • Hagfors and Torsby Loops: Wide, fast stretches with full-throttle commitment—snowbanks offered safety or disaster depending on entry angle.
  • Lesjöfors Region: Narrower stages with fast crests and tight bends—perfect traction made for aggressive driving, but mistakes were punished.
  • Älvdalen Sections: High-speed tests with changing snowpack and deep ruts—called for experience and bravery in equal measure.

Consistent cold kept surfaces firm and ideal for studded tires—Jonsson thrived under those conditions and built a lead few could touch.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Mats Jonsson & Lars Bäckman (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST165)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185)

3rd Place: Ari Vatanen & Bruno Berglund (Subaru Legacy RS)

Jonsson’s underdog victory thrilled the Swedish fans and proved that in snow, local knowledge could still beat newer machinery and full works support.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST165: Outdated on paper but perfectly suited to snow—with light steering and a stable chassis, Jonsson pushed it to its limit.
  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185: The factory car of choice—Sainz stayed close behind, but Jonsson’s momentum was unmatched.
  • Subaru Legacy RS: Ari Vatanen showed the Subaru’s promise on snow—its AWD traction helped it claim a respectable podium.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Snowbanks: Drivers leaned on them for stability—but too deep a slide could mean instant retirement.
  • Studded Tire Management: Maintaining grip required avoiding tire wear across long stage distances.
  • Local Knowledge: Jonsson knew which corners could be pushed and which needed patience—his familiarity proved decisive.

The 1992 Swedish Rally was a reminder that raw pace alone doesn’t win on snow—Jonsson’s smart, fearless drive showed that rallying’s romantic underdog stories were still alive and well.

title: 1992 Rallye de Portugal – Vinho do Porto (Portugal)
bio: François Delecour charged to his first WRC victory in Portugal, taming the foggy gravel and tarmac roads in his Ford Sierra RS Cosworth with a display of raw speed and growing maturity.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Rallye de Portugal – Vinho do Porto (Portugal)

Date: March 3–7, 1992

Start Location: Estoril, Portugal

Finish Location: Porto, Portugal

Total Distance: 541.00 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel and tarmac

The 1992 Rallye de Portugal provided its usual mix of challenging weather, dusty gravel, and occasional asphalt sections in the north. François Delecour, still early in his WRC career, combined pace with newfound composure to take his first-ever World Rally Championship victory. With Daniel Grataloup reading notes, the pair stayed ahead of the factory Toyotas and Lancias, navigating the foggy forests and unpredictable conditions with finesse.

🗺️ Route Details

Portugal’s stages were long, technical, and lined with enthusiastic fans—terrain shifted between hard-packed gravel, rough ruts, and sections of narrow tarmac:

  • Arganil: Foggy mountain passes with loose gravel—visibility often reduced to meters, forcing total trust in pacenotes.
  • Fafe and Lameirinha: Famous jumps and flowing sequences made for high-speed action and high-stakes mistakes.
  • Mortágua Region: Rougher sections with rocks and worn surfaces—punctures and suspension stress were constant risks.

While weather was generally dry, early fog and isolated showers made tire choice difficult—Delecour got it right when it counted most.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Ford Sierra RS Cosworth)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185)

3rd Place: Didier Auriol & Bernard Occelli (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

Delecour’s victory marked a turning point in his career—he showed he could not only push hard but manage risk and race strategy over five brutal days.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4: Balanced and aggressive—suited to fast gravel and quick transitions between grip levels.
  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185: Strong contender—Sainz stayed close but couldn’t close the final gap in slippery sections.
  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Reliable and proven—Auriol used experience to claim yet another podium.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Fog and Fan Crowds: Stages often ran through thick fog with fans inches from the road—distraction and poor visibility were ever-present threats.
  • Tire Discipline: Split-surface stages demanded smart compound compromises—Delecour’s calls gave him a key edge.
  • Stage Length: Many loops were long and punishing—drivers needed to keep energy and focus through double-digit kilometer runs.

The 1992 Rallye de Portugal was the birth of Delecour as a serious title threat—his raw pace matured into race-winning execution on one of the season’s most difficult events.

title: 1992 Safari Rally (Kenya)
bio: Kenjiro Shinozuka mastered Africa’s ultimate endurance rally for a second time, guiding his Mitsubishi Galant VR-4 through the heat, dust, and chaos of Kenya’s unforgiving terrain.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Safari Rally (Kenya)

Date: March 27 – April 1, 1992

Start Location: Nairobi, Kenya

Finish Location: Nairobi, Kenya

Total Distance: 4,040 km (endurance rally format)

Surface: Gravel, dirt, and open road

The 1992 Safari Rally remained the World Rally Championship’s most grueling challenge. Covering over 4,000 kilometers of open African roads, the event tested not just driver speed but mechanical durability, navigation accuracy, and physical endurance. Kenjiro Shinozuka, one of rallying’s African specialists, delivered a composed and tactical drive through punishing terrain. With co-driver John Meadows and the dependable Mitsubishi Galant VR-4, he outlasted the competition to take his second career Safari win.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally's route looped across remote stretches of Kenya, through dusty plains, rocky riverbeds, and rain-drenched savannahs:

  • Mount Kenya Region: High-altitude gravel with foggy mornings, steep inclines, and slippery volcanic rock.
  • Lake Baringo and Eldoret Loops: Dust clouds, wildlife hazards, and surface transitions from sand to sharp rock.
  • Maasai Mara Plains: Open dirt tracks with tall grass, unpredictable weather, and flooded sections after brief storms.

Service areas were sparse, making mechanical preservation and navigational accuracy more important than outright stage speed.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Kenjiro Shinozuka & John Meadows (Mitsubishi Galant VR-4)

2nd Place: Ian Duncan & Ian Munro (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST165)

3rd Place: Ari Vatanen & Bruno Berglund (Subaru Legacy RS)

Shinozuka’s calculated pace and flawless teamwork gave Mitsubishi another legendary Safari win—cementing his place as one of the great African rally drivers.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Mitsubishi Galant VR-4: Built for durability—its rugged suspension, turbocharged power, and stable drivetrain made it ideal for open-road African rallies.
  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST165: Proven in Kenya with Ian Duncan at the wheel—quick and capable, but not quite as resilient over long loops.
  • Subaru Legacy RS: Vatanen pushed hard in Subaru’s endurance build—strong finish despite delays from early mechanical issues.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Mechanical Endurance: Suspensions, tires, and cooling systems were stressed across multiple 1,000 km loops with minimal repair time.
  • Open-Road Format: No traditional special stages—crews raced against the clock on public dirt roads, managing speed and accuracy with route books.
  • Local Hazards: Wildlife crossings, water damage, and navigation errors ended the rally early for several top contenders.

The 1992 Safari Rally remained a monument to endurance rallying—Shinozuka’s victory was equal parts patience, preparation, and raw resolve under Africa’s unforgiving skies.

title: 1992 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (Corsica)
bio: Didier Auriol claimed his fourth consecutive Corsican victory, flawlessly threading his Lancia Delta HF Integrale through the endless corners of the island’s brutal asphalt rally.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (Corsica)

Date: May 2–6, 1992

Start Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Finish Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Total Distance: 535.00 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt

The 1992 Tour de Corse again lived up to its reputation as the “Rally of 10,000 Corners.” Didier Auriol, now firmly established as the master of Corsican tarmac, displayed remarkable precision and rhythm over the mountainous island roads. Driving the Lancia Delta HF Integrale, Auriol and co-driver Bernard Occelli set a relentless pace on each of the rally’s twisting stages, sealing a fourth straight victory in one of the championship’s most unforgiving asphalt events.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally’s stages circled Corsica’s rugged interior, with high-speed switchbacks, narrow hill roads, and sudden elevation changes:

  • Zérubia–Aullène: Long and flowing asphalt ribbon, requiring tire discipline and total commitment through blind bends.
  • Vico–Col de Sevi: Fast downhill sections through pine forests and exposed ridgelines—minimal room for error.
  • Alata–Bocognano: Narrow, bumpy climbs and descents with loose gravel runoff and sharp cliffs.

Dry and sunny weather kept grip levels predictable—Auriol used every kilometer of clean road to extend his lead stage by stage.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Didier Auriol & Bernard Occelli (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

2nd Place: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185)

Auriol’s calm, methodical driving was once again the perfect weapon for Corsica—his pace was untouchable even for the rising asphalt stars behind him.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Agile and well-balanced—its braking and mid-corner stability made it ideal for Corsica’s never-ending corners.
  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4: Fast and composed on smooth tarmac—Delecour was aggressive but couldn’t match Auriol’s fluency.
  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185: Powerful and durable—Sainz relied on clean lines and consistency to lock in another podium finish.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Relentless Cornering: Driver focus and co-driver rhythm were paramount—each stage demanded constant concentration and perfect note delivery.
  • Tire Management: Abrasive tarmac and long loops forced strategic compound choices—Auriol’s Lancia setup minimized wear.
  • Local Knowledge: Corsica’s roads punished hesitation—Auriol’s deep familiarity gave him unmatched confidence through the trickiest sections.

The 1992 Tour de Corse was another masterclass from Didier Auriol, reinforcing his dominance on tight, technical tarmac and extending Lancia’s reign on one of rallying’s most iconic stages.

title: 1992 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
bio: Carlos Sainz tamed the brutal Greek gravel stages in a calculated drive that rewarded resilience and discipline, earning his first win of the 1992 season with the Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Acropolis Rally (Greece)

Date: May 30 – June 3, 1992

Start Location: Athens, Greece

Finish Location: Athens, Greece

Total Distance: 578.00 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1992 Acropolis Rally once again lived up to its reputation as one of the toughest events on the WRC calendar. With sharp rocks, scorching heat, and punishing dust, it became a test of mechanical strength and driver patience. Carlos Sainz and Luis Moya delivered a measured and intelligent performance in their Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185. Their strategy prioritized preservation and consistency, outlasting the competition across the rough terrain to claim a crucial victory in the season's title fight.

🗺️ Route Details

The stages ran through the mountains and dry valleys of central Greece, combining high-speed gravel blasts with technical sections lined with rocks:

  • Elatia and Gravia: Fast, flowing stages with deep dust and narrow lines—visibility was often a challenge.
  • Bauxites and Drossochori: Rugged, uphill terrain littered with sharp stones—a tire and suspension killer.
  • Kallithea and Itea: Sinuous mountain tracks with sheer drops and deep ruts—punished every mistake.

Temperatures soared above 35°C during the rally, turning cockpit conditions into a test of endurance in addition to speed.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185)

2nd Place: Didier Auriol & Bernard Occelli (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

3rd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

Sainz’s strategic pace and low error rate kept him just out of reach—he avoided drama and let the terrain wear down his rivals.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185: Well-suited for the conditions—its tough chassis and consistent torque gave Sainz the balance of speed and durability he needed.
  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Still competitive, but Auriol and Kankkunen lost time to tire wear and cooling issues in extreme heat.
  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth: Showed promise early on but struggled with reliability on rougher stages.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Stone Damage: Constant risk to tires, suspension, and underbody—teams ran reinforced components but still suffered retirements.
  • Heat Fatigue: Driver and co-driver exhaustion was a serious factor across long loops with minimal shade.
  • Stage Length: Many competitive sections were 30–50 km long—required steady focus and mechanical sympathy throughout.

The 1992 Acropolis Rally was survival of the fittest—Sainz’s win was a triumph of strategy, restraint, and the unflinching consistency that defined his title-contending season.

title: 1992 Rally New Zealand (New Zealand)
bio: Carlos Sainz carved through New Zealand’s flowing gravel roads with precision and pace, securing a commanding win in the Celica GT-Four ST185 and strengthening his championship push.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Rally New Zealand (New Zealand)

Date: June 25–28, 1992

Start Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Finish Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Total Distance: 519.00 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1992 Rally New Zealand delivered fast and flowing gravel action through some of the world’s smoothest rally roads. With high-speed crests, cambered corners, and minimal margin for error, the event rewarded rhythm and precision. Carlos Sainz and Luis Moya were flawless in execution, using the Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185’s AWD grip and stability to full effect. Their smooth and assertive drive outpaced the field, marking Sainz’s second consecutive win of the season and tightening the title race considerably.

🗺️ Route Details

The North Island’s iconic rally terrain featured long gravel tests through lush forests and hilly countryside:

  • Whangarei Region: Fast, flowing roads with natural camber—encouraged aggressive cornering and rewarded bravery.
  • Rotorua and Tokoroa Loops: Tight forest paths combined with wide, open hills—demanded varied driving styles and quick adaptability.
  • Maramarua Forest: Slippery when damp with narrow ruts and fast crests—called for perfect pacenote reading and throttle modulation.

Weather remained cool and dry, offering excellent visibility and a consistent racing surface—ideal conditions for Sainz’s smooth style.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185)

2nd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

3rd Place: Ari Vatanen & Bruno Berglund (Subaru Legacy RS)

Sainz’s win in New Zealand was a masterclass in clean, efficient rallying—he kept momentum high and errors to a minimum on roads that punished overconfidence.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185: Strong acceleration and composed handling made it ideal for the fast gravel terrain—Sainz used every advantage to stay ahead.
  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Quick in tighter sections—Kankkunen remained close, but couldn’t match Toyota’s high-speed balance on long stages.
  • Subaru Legacy RS: Durable and nimble—Vatanen continued to show its promise, keeping pressure on the leaders despite fewer stage wins.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Pace Management: Rally New Zealand rewarded maintaining flow—slowing too much in corners lost vital tenths over long distances.
  • Corner Exit Speed: With long straights after bends, clean exits were key—Sainz’s car control was particularly sharp in this aspect.
  • Consistency: No single stage was decisive—this was a rally of cumulative perfection, and Sainz delivered exactly that.

The 1992 Rally New Zealand stood out as a technical rallyist’s paradise—Sainz’s dominant yet measured victory further solidified his status as a master of the smooth and fast.

title: 1992 Rally Argentina (Argentina)
bio: Gustavo Trelles delivered a career-defining performance on the punishing gravel roads of Argentina, guiding his Lancia Delta HF Integrale to a historic home-continent victory.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Rally Argentina (Argentina)

Date: July 22–25, 1992

Start Location: Córdoba, Argentina

Finish Location: Córdoba, Argentina

Total Distance: 623.00 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1992 Rally Argentina proved to be a rugged test of machinery and focus, with fast, rocky stages winding through the hills of Córdoba. South American favorite Gustavo Trelles, driving a privately entered Lancia Delta HF Integrale, shocked the factory teams with a composed and clean drive. His co-driver Jorge del Buono kept the pace sharp throughout the event, while the pair avoided major setbacks to secure an unforgettable victory on their home continent.

🗺️ Route Details

The stages mixed altitude, heavy dust, and hard-packed gravel, often flanked by stone walls and deep drop-offs:

  • Punilla Valley: Technical and narrow with a mix of sandy crests and sharp rock beds—tire preservation was critical.
  • Traslasierra Region: Long open sections where drivers could gain or lose huge time based on risk tolerance.
  • Mina Clavero Stages: Famous for water crossings, riverbed entries, and constant rhythm changes—favored precise throttle work and note reading.

The rally’s dry climate meant massive dust trails and poor visibility, making early gaps in road order crucial. Trelles managed them perfectly.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Gustavo Trelles & Jorge del Buono (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185)

3rd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

Trelles’s victory was a triumph of discipline and consistency—his pace may not have been explosive, but it was relentless and mistake-free in a rally where many faltered.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Known for durability and agility on mixed gravel—Trelles made the most of its predictability and balance.
  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185: More powerful but heavier—Sainz pushed hard but couldn’t overturn Trelles’s lead late in the rally.
  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4: Competitive early but plagued by mechanical issues across the longer loops.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Dust Management: Thick clouds made overtaking nearly impossible and required near-perfect road positioning from the start.
  • Water Hazards: Multiple splashdowns could compromise electrics—several top cars suffered water-related mechanical failures.
  • Fan Proximity: Argentina’s passionate fans lined the routes in force—some sections were made riskier by narrow spectator corridors.

The 1992 Rally Argentina was a showcase of local expertise, fan energy, and calculated grit—Trelles’s win remains one of the most iconic privateer triumphs of the early 1990s.

title: 1992 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)
bio: Markku Alén thrilled the home crowd with a legendary drive through Finland’s fast gravel stages, earning Subaru its first-ever WRC victory behind the wheel of the Legacy RS.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)

Date: August 27–30, 1992

Start Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Finish Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Total Distance: 482.42 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1992 1000 Lakes Rally, famed for its high speeds and massive jumps, saw Finnish legend Markku Alén roll back the years with a spectacular win on home soil. Driving the Subaru Legacy RS, Alén and co-driver Ilkka Kivimäki attacked the flowing forest stages with authority and style. It was a momentous breakthrough for Subaru, marking their first WRC victory and signaling the rise of a new contender in world rallying.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally wound through central Finland’s lakes and woods, featuring fast gravel roads, blind crests, and precision jumps:

  • Ouninpohja: The rally’s most iconic stage—full of rhythm, crests, and commitment. A true driver’s test.
  • Lankamaa and Vaheri: High-speed gravel sweepers with soft shoulders—punished the slightest misjudgment.
  • Ruuhimäki: Narrower and twistier but with some of the biggest jumps of the rally—car control under pressure was essential.

Dry weather allowed maximum attack throughout, with average stage speeds approaching 130 km/h. Alén’s fearlessness and experience made all the difference.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Subaru Legacy RS)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185)

3rd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

The victory was not only a personal triumph for Alén, but a defining moment for Subaru—firmly establishing the Japanese manufacturer as a serious force in WRC competition.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Subaru Legacy RS: AWD turbocharged sedan—finally tuned for top-speed control and jump stability on Finland’s smooth gravel.
  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185: Strong on acceleration and power, but slightly heavier—Sainz kept close but couldn’t match Alén’s rhythm.
  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Struggled slightly in ultra-high-speed sections—still showed remarkable consistency with another podium.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Jump Accuracy: Finnish stages required absolute belief in pacenotes—incorrect jump speed or line could ruin a run.
  • Flow Maintenance: Rally Finland is about momentum—drivers who braked too often lost seconds every kilometer.
  • High-Speed Courage: The 1000 Lakes separates the brave from the bold—Alén knew every crest, every cut, every risk worth taking.

The 1992 1000 Lakes Rally was a perfect storm of speed, local knowledge, and breakthrough performance—Markku Alén and Subaru delivered one for the history books.

title: 1992 Rally Australia (Australia)
bio: Carlos Sainz mastered the Western Australian forests with a clean and commanding performance, extending his championship momentum in the Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Rally Australia (Australia)

Date: September 19–22, 1992

Start Location: Perth, Australia

Finish Location: Perth, Australia

Total Distance: 630.00 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

Held in the eucalyptus-lined forests around Perth, the 1992 Rally Australia provided a fast, technical challenge filled with narrow paths, loose surfaces, and blinding dust. Carlos Sainz and Luis Moya rose to the occasion with a near-flawless drive. Leveraging the Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185’s balance and traction, Sainz controlled the event from early on, showing championship-worthy form in one of the calendar’s trickiest gravel events.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally ran through the tight, technical forests of Western Australia, combining fast transitions with low grip and minimal visibility:

  • Mundaring and Bunnings Loops: Narrow gravel paths with trees hugging both sides—required pinpoint precision.
  • Wellington Dam Region: Fast flowing gravel and mid-speed crests—dust played a major factor in car spacing.
  • Helena and Nannup Stages: Rougher terrain with sharp bends and loose corners—punished even minor braking errors.

Dry, dusty weather favored clean air for front runners. Sainz took full advantage of his starting position to establish an early lead.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185)

2nd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

3rd Place: Ari Vatanen & Bruno Berglund (Subaru Legacy RS)

Sainz’s calculated and consistent drive minimized mistakes and tire wear, helping him edge closer to the WRC title with a third win of the season.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185: Exceptionally well-balanced in dry gravel—strong torque and responsive handling made it ideal for Australia’s terrain.
  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Competitive in rough sections—Kankkunen kept pace but couldn’t match Sainz’s line discipline.
  • Subaru Legacy RS: Fast and durable—Vatanen impressed again with clean stage times and another strong finish for Subaru.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Dust Management: Dense trails made visibility difficult—Sainz's front-running start was strategically important.
  • Tree-Lined Margins: The narrowness of many stages left zero room for mistakes—Sainz’s composure was key.
  • Consistent Surface Changes: From smooth gravel to patchy loose dirt, traction varied stage-to-stage—demanding constant adjustment in driving style.

The 1992 Rally Australia tested every element of a rally team—Carlos Sainz and Toyota delivered a textbook win through the heat, dust, and shadows of the Perth forests.

title: 1992 Paris–Moscow–Beijing Rally (Europe–Asia)
bio: Pierre Lartigue and Michel Périn conquered one of rallying’s longest-ever events, guiding their Citroën ZX Rallye Raid across 16,000 km of Eurasian terrain from the heart of Europe to the edge of the Pacific.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Paris–Moscow–Beijing Rally

Date: August 1–27, 1992

Start Location: Paris, France

Finish Location: Beijing, China

Total Distance: ~16,000 km (mixed-terrain endurance rally)

Surface: Asphalt, gravel, sand, and off-road

The 1992 Paris–Moscow–Beijing Rally was a transcontinental marathon designed to unite Europe and Asia through motorsport. Spanning almost an entire month, it crossed national borders, time zones, and landscapes from urban Europe to the deserts of Central Asia and finally into the vast Chinese heartland. Pierre Lartigue and co-driver Michel Périn delivered an authoritative and consistent performance in their Citroën ZX Rallye Raid, claiming victory after nearly 16,000 kilometers of relentless competition.

🗺️ Route Details

The route offered a unique blend of historic cities, remote wilderness, and vast open deserts—requiring logistical precision and rugged reliability:

  • France to Russia: Asphalt liaison through Western Europe, transitioning to rougher roads across Poland and Belarus.
  • Russian Steppes: Endless gravel plains and dirt roads across the Ural Mountains and Siberia—navigation was crucial with few landmarks.
  • Mongolia and China: Sand dunes, remote highlands, and dry riverbeds—drivers battled dust, isolation, and long daily stages under blazing skies.

The event demanded unmatched mechanical reliability, with teams covering multiple 800+ km stages between limited bivouac-style service points.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Pierre Lartigue & Michel Périn (Citroën ZX Rallye Raid)

2nd Place: Hubert Auriol & Philippe Monnet (Citroën ZX Rallye Raid)

3rd Place: Jean-Louis Schlesser & François Borsotto (Schlesser-Renault Buggy)

Lartigue’s experience, combined with Périn’s navigational mastery, proved unbeatable over the vast Eurasian landscape—their Citroën never missed a beat.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën ZX Rallye Raid: Lightweight, turbocharged endurance prototype—purpose-built for rally raid reliability and comfort over long stages.
  • Schlesser-Renault Buggy: Agile and powerful—fast on sand and compact routes but required more maintenance over the longer segments.
  • Mitsubishi Pajero: Strong privateer presence—many finished thanks to mechanical robustness despite limited support.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Cross-Continental Logistics: Coordinating border crossings, fuel, and mechanical assistance across 16,000 km was a major feat for teams and organizers.
  • Fatigue and Heat: Crews faced dehydration, equipment stress, and extreme isolation—especially across Mongolia’s deserts and Chinese interior.
  • Navigation: Vast open spaces meant teams had to rely on compass work and limited waypoints—Périn’s accuracy made the difference for Lartigue.

The 1992 Paris–Moscow–Beijing Rally was more than a race—it was an expedition. Lartigue’s win was a triumph of endurance, professionalism, and transcontinental ambition.

title: 1992 Rallye Sanremo – Rallye d’Italia (Italy)
bio: Andrea Aghini claimed an emotional first WRC win for Lancia on home soil in a Sanremo rally shortened by political tension and team withdrawals.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Rallye Sanremo – Rallye d’Italia (Italy)

Date: October 12–15, 1992

Start Location: Sanremo, Italy

Finish Location: Sanremo, Italy

Total Distance: 390.00 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt

The 1992 Sanremo Rally, typically one of the calendar’s premier asphalt events, was marred by controversy. Following tensions over perceived event management and road fairness, several top WRC teams curtailed their participation. Despite the disrupted field, Lancia local Andrea Aghini and co-driver Simone Scattolin kept focus and delivered a controlled and inspired drive. The result was Aghini’s first—and only—WRC win, fittingly aboard the legendary Delta HF Integrale on Italian tarmac.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally unfolded in the Ligurian mountains above the Italian Riviera—classic Sanremo territory with smooth asphalt, constant direction changes, and tight switchbacks:

  • Monte Ceppo: Fast and flowing with long descents—traction and braking precision were essential.
  • San Bartolomeo and Col di Nava: Technical hill stages with quick elevation changes and slippery early-morning surfaces.
  • Bajardo and Vignai: Iconic Italian tarmac with narrow stone-lined sections—demanded precision and courage.

The rally was cut short amid intra-team disagreements and championship politics, leaving many top crews with incomplete results—but Aghini’s performance stood regardless.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Andrea Aghini & Simone Scattolin (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185)

3rd Place: Didier Auriol & Bernard Occelli (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

Though not without controversy, Aghini’s pace on the asphalt was undeniable—he outdrove experienced rivals and became a national hero in the process.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Arguably past its peak, but still precise and durable—Aghini pushed it to the limit with great effect.
  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185: Sainz kept pressure on but struggled slightly with understeer on tighter hairpins.
  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4: Showed pace in early stages but faded after teams reevaluated participation.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Event Tension: Political disputes and protests over fairness led to a fragmented field—focus was difficult for many teams.
  • Precision Driving: Italian tarmac rallies punish overdriving—Aghini’s smoothness proved decisive on narrow switchbacks.
  • Championship Disruption: Some points contenders withdrew, leaving standings shaken by the unusual conditions.

Though shortened and controversial, the 1992 Rallye Sanremo will always be remembered as the day Andrea Aghini delivered for Lancia on Italian home ground.

title: 1992 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire – Bandama (Ivory Coast)
bio: Kenjiro Shinozuka delivered another masterful performance on African soil, conquering the brutal endurance challenge of Côte d’Ivoire in the Mitsubishi Galant VR-4.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire – Bandama (Ivory Coast)

Date: October 31 – November 3, 1992

Start Location: Abidjan, Ivory Coast

Finish Location: Abidjan, Ivory Coast

Total Distance: 3,056 km (2,143 km competitive)

Surface: Gravel, laterite, dirt tracks

The 1992 Rallye Côte d’Ivoire remained a brutal test of stamina, vehicle preservation, and navigational skill. With long stages, high humidity, and little margin for error, it stood as the last of the great African endurance rallies on the WRC calendar. Kenjiro Shinozuka, well-versed in the demands of African terrain, paired with co-driver John Meadows to guide their Mitsubishi Galant VR-4 to victory—his second win in Ivory Coast and another jewel in Mitsubishi’s rally raid résumé.

🗺️ Route Details

This grueling open-road rally wound through the Ivory Coast’s dusty trails, jungle tracks, and remote river crossings:

  • Abidjan to Yamoussoukro: High-speed straights over laterite—drivers faced severe dust and blazing heat from the outset.
  • Interior Forest Loops: Narrow two-track roads, mud ruts, and village crossings—navigation and local knowledge were critical.
  • Return to Coast: Mechanical fatigue became the biggest threat—teams often ran with reduced service availability and relied on field repairs.

With no traditional special stages, teams drove long loops against the clock over public and remote roads—reliability and survival came before outright speed.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Kenjiro Shinozuka & John Meadows (Mitsubishi Galant VR-4)

2nd Place: Alain Ambrosino & Jean-Claude Lemoine (Nissan Sunny GTI)

3rd Place: Patrick Tauziac & Claude Papin (Mitsubishi Galant VR-4)

Shinozuka’s calm, methodical drive through extreme conditions reaffirmed his status as a true African rally specialist—he outlasted the chaos while others fell victim to it.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Mitsubishi Galant VR-4: Proven durable in Africa—its AWD system and torque-rich engine thrived in tough, high-speed open-road stages.
  • Nissan Sunny GTI: Lighter and nimbler—Ambrosino pushed hard but couldn’t match the Galant’s toughness on longer loops.
  • Peugeot 504 Pickup (support class): Dominated utility classes and assisted privateers—further proof of local endurance rally ingenuity.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Route Complexity: Minimal signage meant co-drivers had to manage timecards, distances, and terrain changes without GPS or errors.
  • Heat and Fatigue: Cockpit temperatures exceeded 50°C, and long stages demanded mental sharpness over 10–12 hour days.
  • Mechanical Attrition: Only a handful of cars finished without serious issues—Shinozuka’s steady hand on the car kept it alive to the finish.

The 1992 Côte d’Ivoire Rally showcased the last great breath of rallying’s marathon era—Shinozuka’s victory was as much about endurance as it was about elite rally skill.

title: 1992 Rallye de España – Catalunya (Spain)
bio: Didier Auriol delivered a dominant performance on the winding tarmac of Catalunya, securing another asphalt victory for Lancia in the twilight of the Delta HF Integrale’s WRC dominance.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Rallye de España – Catalunya (Spain)

Date: November 9–11, 1992

Start Location: Lloret de Mar, Spain

Finish Location: Lloret de Mar, Spain

Total Distance: 521.00 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt

The 1992 Rallye de España – Catalunya delivered a high-speed tarmac challenge through the Catalan mountains. Didier Auriol and Bernard Occelli once again proved untouchable on sealed surfaces, maintaining a smooth and aggressive rhythm in their Lancia Delta HF Integrale. As the rally evolved into a tightly contested affair, Auriol’s confidence and precision made the difference, extending Lancia’s legacy in what would be one of its final victories at the top level of WRC competition.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally traversed the scenic but treacherous roads of northeastern Spain, packed with hairpins, crests, and surface changes:

  • La Trona and Els Àngels: Smooth and fast asphalt mountain roads with sweeping curves and sudden elevation changes.
  • Santa Coloma and Viladrau: Narrow and technical hill climbs—traction and rhythm were critical.
  • Ripoll Region: Cold mornings brought patches of damp, forcing careful tire strategies and early caution.

Weather remained largely dry, with cool temperatures helping to preserve tires throughout the event’s long, winding stages.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Didier Auriol & Bernard Occelli (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185)

3rd Place: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4)

Auriol’s performance was another testament to his asphalt mastery, holding off a charging Sainz on home soil and reinforcing Lancia’s strength in the dying days of the Group A era.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: A proven asphalt weapon—its agile chassis and consistent braking gave Auriol the edge on Spain’s technical roads.
  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185: Quick and powerful—Sainz impressed on home ground, but couldn’t quite match Auriol’s corner-to-corner finesse.
  • Ford Sierra RS Cosworth 4x4: Still competitive on tarmac—Delecour pushed hard but lost time in tighter sections.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Precision Braking: Spain’s tarmac demanded deep late braking—Auriol was clinical in threshold management throughout.
  • Traction Variation: Damp patches in the shadows made grip unpredictable, especially on early morning loops.
  • Championship Pressure: With points on the line, every second counted—Auriol stayed calm while others made costly errors.

The 1992 Catalunya rally proved once more that Auriol was a tarmac virtuoso—his win marked one of the final high notes for the Lancia dynasty in WRC.

title: 1992 Lombard RAC Rally (Great Britain)
bio: Colin McRae etched his name into rallying history with a fearless performance through the British forests, securing his first WRC win and Subaru’s rise to prominence.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1992 Lombard RAC Rally (Great Britain)

Date: November 22–25, 1992

Start Location: Chester, England

Finish Location: Chester, England

Total Distance: 527.80 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1992 RAC Rally marked a generational shift in the World Rally Championship as 24-year-old Colin McRae stormed to a breakthrough victory on home soil. Driving the Subaru Legacy RS with co-driver Derek Ringer, McRae attacked the muddy and fog-filled stages of Wales and Northern England with fearless commitment. His aggressive style thrilled fans and signaled the arrival of a new rally star, while giving Subaru its second WRC win—and its first in Europe.

🗺️ Route Details

As usual, the RAC Rally delivered a blend of fast gravel forest stages and technical woodland routes, often shrouded in mist and lined with slippery leaves:

  • Kielder Forest: High-speed gravel with narrow tree-lined paths—mistakes punished instantly.
  • Clocaenog and Hafren: Rolling Welsh stages with mixed grip and tricky rhythm—known for deep mud and fog.
  • Dalby and Sherwood: Slippery with tight corners—demanded clean pacenotes and tire discipline in changing weather.

Weather was cold and damp throughout the event. McRae thrived in the changing conditions, often taking risks others avoided—many paid off spectacularly.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Colin McRae & Derek Ringer (Subaru Legacy RS)

2nd Place: Ari Vatanen & Bruno Berglund (Subaru Legacy RS)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185)

McRae’s win ignited a new era for British rallying—he became the youngest winner of the RAC and gave Subaru a powerful foothold in the WRC narrative.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Subaru Legacy RS: Strong chassis and all-wheel-drive traction made it ideal for British conditions—McRae exploited every inch of its handling.
  • Toyota Celica GT-Four ST185: Consistent and fast—Sainz stayed in contention but couldn’t match McRae’s flat-out approach.
  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Still competitive, but showing signs of age against the next generation of turbo AWD machines.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Fog and Rain: Classic British rally weather reduced visibility to meters at times—McRae adapted quickly and pushed hard regardless.
  • Mud and Grip Shifts: Constant surface changes made tire choice and car setup critical throughout the rally.
  • Youthful Bravery: McRae’s aggressive confidence gave him the edge—where others lifted, he pressed on.

The 1992 RAC Rally launched a legend—Colin McRae’s fearless charge through the forests became an instant classic and a defining moment for Subaru in world rallying.

title: 1993 Paris–Dakar Rally (Paris–Tanger–Dakar)
bio: Bruno Saby and Dominique Serieys navigated the shifting sands of North and West Africa with grit and precision, piloting their Mitsubishi Pajero to a landmark victory in the legendary desert marathon.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1993 Paris–Dakar Rally (Paris–Tanger–Dakar)

Date: January 1–16, 1993

Start Location: Paris, France

Finish Location: Dakar, Senegal

Total Distance: 8,877 km (4,476 km competitive)

Surface: Sand, gravel, rock, and off-road desert terrain

The 1993 Paris–Dakar Rally carried competitors from the winter streets of France to the sun-blasted dunes of Senegal. Through Morocco, Mauritania, and the heart of the Sahara, drivers faced shifting sands, rocky passes, and extreme fatigue. Bruno Saby, a veteran of WRC and raid events, paired with Dominique Serieys to win in a Mitsubishi Pajero, leveraging mechanical durability, strategic navigation, and a measured driving style. Their victory marked another milestone for Mitsubishi in its long raid racing legacy.

🗺️ Route Details

The trans-African rally traversed diverse and hostile environments over two weeks of intense competition:

  • France to Tangier: Liaison stages from Paris to the ferry crossing—civilian roads with timed checkpoints.
  • Morocco: Rocky pistes and dry valleys—suspension stress and dust management were early concerns.
  • Mauritania and Senegal: Deep sand, erg crossings, and navigation-by-compass through dunes—where the rally was won or lost.

Fatigue, navigation errors, and mechanical strain thinned the field each day—Saby and Serieys avoided drama, built consistency, and pounced when rivals faltered.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Bruno Saby & Dominique Serieys (Mitsubishi Pajero)

2nd Place: Hubert Auriol & Philippe Monnet (Citroën ZX Rallye Raid)

3rd Place: Ari Vatanen & Bruno Berglund (Peugeot 405 T16 Grand Raid)

Saby’s win added his name to Dakar’s elite and gave Mitsubishi another dominant showing in raid racing’s most storied event.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Mitsubishi Pajero: A raid veteran—reliable, stable, and powerful across both dunes and rocky terrain. Its mix of ruggedness and speed proved unbeatable in 1993.
  • Citroën ZX Rallye Raid: Technologically advanced and agile—Auriol stayed in contention but couldn’t match the Pajero’s bulletproof reliability.
  • Peugeot 405 T16 Grand Raid: Vatanen’s speed was undeniable, but navigation issues and delays kept him off the top step.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Desert Navigation: GPS was limited—teams used compass bearings and road books in featureless dunes.
  • Fatigue Management: Crews drove 10–12 hours per day for two weeks—mental stamina was as critical as vehicle condition.
  • Mechanical Survival: Heat and sand damaged radiators, brakes, and engines—Saby’s conservative approach helped avoid costly breakdowns.

The 1993 Dakar wasn’t about raw speed—it was about resilience, precision, and endurance. Bruno Saby’s victory was a masterclass in how to conquer the world’s toughest rally.

title: 1993 Rallye Monte-Carlo (Monaco)
bio: François Delecour claimed a breakthrough win in Monte Carlo, taming the treacherous mix of snow and asphalt in his Ford Escort RS Cosworth with a calculated and confident drive.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1993 Rallye Monte-Carlo (Monaco)

Date: January 23–27, 1993

Start Location: Valence, France

Finish Location: Monte Carlo, Monaco

Total Distance: 644.00 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt and snow

The 1993 Monte Carlo Rally delivered its trademark mix of unpredictability and spectacle. Snow-covered alpine roads and dry tarmac in the valleys challenged teams with constantly shifting grip. François Delecour, behind the wheel of the Ford Escort RS Cosworth, maintained calm under pressure. With near-perfect tire calls and precise execution, he and co-driver Daniel Grataloup overcame fierce competition to take their maiden WRC victory in one of rallying’s most prestigious events.

🗺️ Route Details

The route spanned southeastern France and the Maritime Alps, with dramatic elevation changes and icy switchbacks:

  • Col de Turini: Iconic hairpin stage often snowbound—timing and tire choice were vital.
  • Saint-Bonnet–Sisteron: Mixed surface with patches of black ice and dry runs—traction strategy determined pace.
  • Burzet–Lalouvesc: Long and fast asphalt sectors with intermittent snowfields—demanded rhythm and confidence.

Monte Carlo’s notorious unpredictability saw conditions change hourly. Delecour’s team made bold but correct decisions on tire compounds, giving him a crucial advantage.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Ford Escort RS Cosworth)

2nd Place: Didier Auriol & Bernard Occelli (Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

Delecour’s calm under pressure and flawless grip management earned him a commanding and well-earned first Monte Carlo victory, announcing Ford’s serious title intentions for the season.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Escort RS Cosworth: Turbocharged, AWD, and nimble—its balance on mixed surfaces gave Delecour the confidence to push in both snow and dry.
  • Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD: Fast and durable—Auriol matched pace but lost key seconds on incorrect tire choices in icy sectors.
  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Still competitive in the snow—Sainz kept pressure on but couldn’t sustain podium pace in drying conditions.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Mixed Surface Mastery: Delecour managed snow-to-dry transitions better than his rivals—especially in early-stage descents.
  • Tire Gambling: Teams had to guess compound choices with minimal weather data—Ford’s calls gave them the upper hand.
  • Pressure Management: Delecour stayed composed against more experienced rivals—his maturity showed in every sector.

The 1993 Monte Carlo Rally crowned a new asphalt king—François Delecour delivered a masterclass in conditions where chaos is the norm, leading Ford to one of its proudest rally moments.

title: 1993 International Swedish Rally (Sweden)
bio: Mats Jonsson dominated the icy forests of Sweden once again, using his local knowledge and precise car control to claim back-to-back wins in the Ford Escort RS Cosworth.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1993 International Swedish Rally (Sweden)

Date: February 12–14, 1993

Start Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Finish Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Total Distance: 448.00 km of special stages

Surface: Snow and ice

The 1993 Swedish Rally was a true winter classic—high speeds, icy roads, and snowbanks lining every turn. Swedish specialist Mats Jonsson capitalized on home advantage and winter driving mastery to dominate the event. With Lars Bäckman calling the notes, Jonsson kept his Ford Escort RS Cosworth perfectly on the limit throughout the snow-covered forests, holding off a stacked international field and taking a popular victory in front of passionate local fans.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally traversed Sweden’s Värmland region, offering a mix of tight tree-lined stages and flat-out snow-covered straights:

  • Rämmen and Fredriksberg: Classic high-speed snow stages with sweeping curves and narrow gaps between snowbanks.
  • Lesjöfors: Featured fast crests, compressed landings, and deep ruts—traction and commitment were everything.
  • Hagfors and Lima Loops: Technical night stages with tricky braking zones and visibility challenges through frozen pine forests.

Temperatures remained consistently below freezing, giving crews optimal conditions for studded tires and stable grip—rewarding experience and precision driving.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Mats Jonsson & Lars Bäckman (Ford Escort RS Cosworth)

2nd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Piironen (Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD)

3rd Place: Ari Vatanen & Bruno Berglund (Subaru Legacy RS)

Jonsson’s clean and blisteringly fast run through the snow-capped forests sealed his status as Sweden’s premier rally driver of the era, giving Ford another winter victory.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Escort RS Cosworth: Well-balanced and stable at speed—perfectly suited to snow rallying with predictable handling and solid traction.
  • Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD: Strong and composed—Kankkunen was consistent but lacked the razor-edge precision of Jonsson on home ground.
  • Subaru Legacy RS: Improving steadily—Vatanen’s podium hinted at Subaru’s growing form heading into the mid-1990s.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Snowbank Strategy: Drivers leaned on snowbanks for cornering support—too much risked sucking the car in, too little sacrificed pace.
  • Frozen Crests: Long, blind jumps required full trust in pacenotes and proper landing lines to maintain momentum.
  • Night Driving: Visibility under snow-glare headlights made concentration critical—especially on the twisty Hagfors loops.

The 1993 Swedish Rally showcased the elegance of ice driving—Mats Jonsson proved once more that mastery of winter rallying belongs to those who live it year-round.

title: 1993 Rallye de Portugal – Vinho do Porto (Portugal)
bio: François Delecour followed up his Monte Carlo success with a commanding victory in Portugal, proving the Ford Escort RS Cosworth’s pace across both gravel and tarmac.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1993 Rallye de Portugal – Vinho do Porto (Portugal)

Date: March 3–6, 1993

Start Location: Estoril, Portugal

Finish Location: Porto, Portugal

Total Distance: 541.00 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel and tarmac

The 1993 Rallye de Portugal brought fast, dusty gravel mixed with tarmac specials and unpredictable spring weather. François Delecour, fresh from his Monte Carlo triumph, stayed aggressive from the outset and handled the transition between surfaces with confidence. His Ford Escort RS Cosworth handled the gravel beautifully, while his tarmac pace was unmatched. Co-driver Daniel Grataloup ensured clean navigation throughout, and together they dominated the event with strategic tire choices and relentless pace.

🗺️ Route Details

Portugal’s mixed-surface challenge featured everything from soft gravel to narrow tarmac lanes, often surrounded by passionate—and dangerously close—crowds:

  • Arganil and Lousã: Classic Portuguese gravel—dusty, fast, and lined with cliffs and fans just feet away from the cars.
  • Sintra and Ponte de Lima: Asphalt stages with slick corners and surprise surface changes—demanded clean tire management.
  • Freita Mountains: Long, fog-prone stages through mountainous gravel roads—pace notes had to be perfect.

The event’s changing conditions caught out many top drivers, but Delecour adapted quickly and never lost momentum once in the lead.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Ford Escort RS Cosworth)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

3rd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Nicky Grist (Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD)

Delecour’s back-to-back victories cemented his and Ford’s credibility as real title threats in 1993—Portugal was a masterclass in adaptability and stage control.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Escort RS Cosworth: Balanced, turbocharged, and agile—excellent on both tarmac and gravel with responsive handling and dependable grip.
  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Still potent, especially in rougher sections—Sainz made few mistakes but couldn’t match Delecour’s road feel on asphalt.
  • Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD: Fast and durable—Kankkunen held strong pace but lost time in early gravel loops.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Surface Transitions: Switching between gravel and tarmac tested car setup and driver adaptability—Delecour handled both effortlessly.
  • Spectator Risk: Portugal’s stages were lined with fans—staying focused through chaotic scenes required nerves of steel.
  • Weather Variability: Intermittent rain added unpredictability, especially on worn tarmac stages—tire choices were crucial to staying ahead.

The 1993 Rallye de Portugal was a perfect demonstration of composure and versatility—Delecour’s second win of the season showed he was no longer an underdog, but a favorite.

title: 1993 Safari Rally (Kenya)
bio: Ian Duncan made history by becoming the first Kenyan to win a WRC round outright, conquering the grueling Safari Rally in a faultless drive across the punishing terrain of East Africa.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1993 Safari Rally (Kenya)

Date: April 7–12, 1993

Start Location: Nairobi, Kenya

Finish Location: Nairobi, Kenya

Total Distance: ~2,019 km (competitive sections)

Surface: Gravel, rocky tracks, and open-road

The 1993 Safari Rally delivered the ultimate endurance challenge across Kenya’s wild terrain. Deep ruts, river crossings, blinding dust, and mechanical attrition defined this marathon event. Ian Duncan, a local hero with unmatched experience in the region, stunned the world by winning in his Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD. Partnered with co-driver Frank Main, Duncan kept calm under pressure and minimized errors while international stars faltered. His historic win marked the first (and only) WRC overall victory by a Kenyan driver.

🗺️ Route Details

The Safari’s massive competitive distance and brutal conditions separated it from every other WRC round:

  • Mount Kenya Loop: Rough, elevated terrain with shifting rocks and washouts—navigation and tire wear were major factors.
  • Great Rift Valley: Long open-road runs through wildlife reserves—top speed and durability mattered more than cornering agility.
  • Amboseli & Athi River Stages: Dust clouds reduced visibility to near zero, while dry riverbeds and rocky tracks battered suspension systems.

The rally remained a point-to-point endurance event with minimal traditional stages—requiring more rally raid strategy than conventional stage racing.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Ian Duncan & Frank Main (Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD)

2nd Place: Markku Alén & Ilkka Kivimäki (Subaru Legacy RS)

3rd Place: Ari Vatanen & Bruno Berglund (Mitsubishi Galant VR-4)

Duncan’s victory was as much about endurance and mechanical preservation as outright pace—his understanding of local terrain made the difference when rivals suffered breakdowns and delays.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD: Strong in high-speed straights and robust in rough conditions—Duncan’s car survived where others didn’t.
  • Subaru Legacy RS: Quick and composed—Alén stayed close but couldn’t match Duncan’s local edge in unpredictable terrain.
  • Mitsubishi Galant VR-4: Powerful and durable—Vatanen was quick but faced delays from mechanical issues mid-event.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Endurance Format: With timed road sections and few service breaks, teams had to balance speed with long-haul reliability.
  • Local Conditions: African weather and terrain fluctuated daily—mud, dust, wildlife, and locals made every kilometer unpredictable.
  • Navigation Accuracy: Missed waypoints or wrong turns cost precious time—Main’s experience with local navigation was key.

The 1993 Safari Rally wasn’t just won on pace—it was won through survival, resilience, and deep local knowledge. Ian Duncan’s victory became a legendary chapter in WRC history.

title: 1993 Lombard London–Sydney Marathon (UK to Australia)
bio: Francis Tuthill and Anthony Showell triumphed in the epic 1993 London–Sydney Marathon, completing an incredible 16,000 km journey across continents in a vintage Porsche 911.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1993 Lombard London–Sydney Marathon

Date: April 17 – May 16, 1993

Start Location: London, United Kingdom

Finish Location: Sydney, Australia

Total Distance: ~16,000 km (mixed surfaces)

Surface: Asphalt, gravel, desert, and open-road stages

Commemorating the legendary 1968 event, the 1993 Lombard London–Sydney Marathon spanned 16,000 kilometers across Europe, Asia, and Australia. Featuring a blend of vintage and modern vehicles, the rally tested endurance, navigation, and mechanical resilience across three continents. Francis Tuthill and Anthony Showell, driving a classic Porsche 911, paced themselves with precision and grit, emerging victorious after one of the most demanding long-distance rallies ever held in the modern era.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally’s route passed through historic and treacherous terrain, echoing the original marathon’s globe-spanning ambition:

  • Europe: UK, France, Italy, and Eastern Europe—tight tarmac stages, snowy mountain passes, and liaison routes through historic cities.
  • Asia: Turkey, Iran, Pakistan, and India—desert heat, gravel sections, and remote villages with limited service access.
  • Australia: Arrival via airlift, with stages from Perth to Sydney—outback tracks, long red-dust trails, and classic rally loops.

Crews faced political, logistical, and physical challenges—navigating unfamiliar cultures, border crossings, and changing road laws while keeping vehicles intact across extreme climates.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Francis Tuthill & Anthony Showell (Porsche 911)

2nd Place: Phil Surtees & Peter Watt (Ford Capri)

3rd Place: Nick Brittan & Steve Hall (Volvo 144)

Tuthill’s steady hand and deep understanding of classic rally mechanics allowed his Porsche 911 to withstand the strain of a month-long race across unforgiving terrain.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Porsche 911: Lightweight, rear-engine layout gave superb traction in varied terrain—Tuthill’s expert preparation made the difference.
  • Ford Capri: Quick and powerful—survived the desert sections but lacked the Porsche’s agility in tight and rough stages.
  • Volvo 144: A durable underdog—outlasted many faster cars through sheer mechanical resilience.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Multi-Continent Complexity: Language barriers, fuel issues, and mechanical support logistics across three continents required strategic foresight.
  • Heat and Altitude: From snowy Alps to Iranian deserts—engines and drivers were pushed to their physical limits.
  • Mechanical Preservation: Classic cars needed constant upkeep—Tuthill’s rally preparation and mechanical experience were decisive.

The 1993 London–Sydney Marathon honored rallying’s grandest adventures—Tuthill’s victory in a vintage Porsche was a celebration of both man and machine over distance, time, and adversity.

title: 1993 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (Corsica)
bio: Didier Auriol reaffirmed his asphalt dominance with a masterful win in Corsica, guiding the Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD through relentless corners and technical tarmac with unshakable precision.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1993 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (Corsica)

Date: May 2–4, 1993

Start Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Finish Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Total Distance: 422.80 km of special stages

Surface: Asphalt

The 1993 Tour de Corse lived up to its nickname—“Rally of 10,000 Corners”—with narrow mountain roads and zero room for error. Didier Auriol, the undisputed master of Corsican tarmac, once again showed his class, dominating in the Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD. With flawless co-driving from Bernard Occelli, Auriol carved through the technical stages with surgical control, outpacing a competitive field and continuing his dominance on French soil.

🗺️ Route Details

Corsica’s stages wound through coastal cliffs and inland hills, demanding rhythm, braking accuracy, and total driver commitment:

  • Zicavo and Quenza Loops: Fast, flowing sections with steep drop-offs and quick elevation changes.
  • Piana and Evisa: Tight, twisty corners through rock-lined roads—precision braking and perfect lines were essential.
  • Sartène Region: Slick, shaded tarmac made grip levels unpredictable—especially on early morning runs.

Dry weather provided consistent conditions, allowing Auriol to extract maximum performance from his Celica’s setup without the threat of rain-induced chaos.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Didier Auriol & Bernard Occelli (Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD)

2nd Place: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Ford Escort RS Cosworth)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

Auriol’s Tour de Corse victory was a calculated display of technical mastery, giving Toyota a significant boost in their championship pursuit and adding to his legendary Corsican resume.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD: Well-balanced, stable under braking, and powerful off apexes—ideal for Corsica’s stop-and-go rhythm.
  • Ford Escort RS Cosworth: Sharp and agile—Delecour pushed hard but couldn’t match Auriol’s consistency on longer loops.
  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Still capable, but beginning to show its age—Sainz extracted the most but lacked the edge needed for a win.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Precision Driving: With hundreds of corners per day, rhythm and mental stamina were just as important as speed.
  • Brake Management: Long descents and repetitive braking zones tested cooling systems and pedal feel across every leg.
  • Line Accuracy: The difference between a perfect stage and retirement could be a few inches—Auriol never missed his mark.

The 1993 Tour de Corse was a showcase of asphalt excellence—Didier Auriol once again proved why Corsica was his kingdom, delivering Toyota a flawless performance.

title: 1993 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
bio: Juha Kankkunen and Nicky Grist delivered a commanding win through the brutal Greek terrain, proving both their endurance and the rugged power of the Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1993 Acropolis Rally (Greece)

Date: May 30 – June 1, 1993

Start Location: Athens, Greece

Finish Location: Athens, Greece

Total Distance: 316.00 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The Acropolis Rally once again lived up to its reputation as one of the most punishing rounds of the WRC. With rocks, dust, heat, and relentless attrition, only the toughest crews survived. Juha Kankkunen, a master of rough rallies, teamed up with co-driver Nicky Grist to dominate the Greek stages in their Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD. Smooth, composed, and strategic, Kankkunen avoided the carnage that caught out many rivals, securing a pivotal win in the championship race.

🗺️ Route Details

Greece’s dry mountain terrain offered intense punishment for both machines and crews, with temperatures climbing above 35°C:

  • Loutraki and Dervenochoria: Fast, wide gravel with rock fields and high speeds—bravery rewarded, but caution kept tires alive.
  • Mount Parnassus Region: Rougher terrain, narrow switchbacks, and steep climbs with thick dust limiting visibility.
  • Kato Tithorea and Aghii Theodori: Classic Acropolis brutality—loose stones and sharp ruts ensured high attrition.

Rocks, overheating, and broken suspensions ended many hopes early—Kankkunen’s conservative start paid dividends as others dropped out or suffered delays.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Juha Kankkunen & Nicky Grist (Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD)

2nd Place: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Ford Escort RS Cosworth)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

Kankkunen’s calculated aggression and deep experience in rough events allowed him to rise above the chaos and give Toyota another vital win on the road to the title.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD: Durable and composed—perfect for rocky terrain, with great power delivery and suspension strength.
  • Ford Escort RS Cosworth: Quick in smoother sections, but vulnerable to damage in the harshest zones.
  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Steady but aging—Sainz’s skill kept it in the fight but reliability began to show limits.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Extreme Heat: Engine temps and cockpit fatigue were constant threats—hydration and mechanical sympathy were critical.
  • Rock Hazards: Punctures and cracked suspensions ended several podium bids—Kankkunen avoided nearly all major risks.
  • Visibility Issues: Dust hung thick in valleys—slower cars ahead could destroy a leader’s rhythm without careful spacing.

The 1993 Acropolis Rally rewarded survival and strategic patience—Kankkunen embodied both, steering Toyota to a flawless finish in one of the world’s toughest events.

title: 1993 Rally Argentina (Argentina)
bio: Uruguayan driver Gustavo Trelles claimed a landmark WRC win in the punishing gravel stages of Argentina, mastering the terrain in his dependable Lancia Delta HF Integrale.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1993 Rally Argentina (Argentina)

Date: July 14–17, 1993

Start Location: Córdoba, Argentina

Finish Location: Córdoba, Argentina

Total Distance: 633.00 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1993 Rally Argentina delivered the traditional blend of fast gravel, water crossings, and high-altitude tests through the Sierras de Córdoba. In a surprise result, Gustavo Trelles of Uruguay, driving the seasoned Lancia Delta HF Integrale, took overall victory—becoming one of the few South American drivers to win a WRC event. Paired with Jorge del Buono, Trelles executed a steady and resilient drive, avoiding the pitfalls that took down quicker rivals and leveraging the Integrale’s reliability across four demanding days.

🗺️ Route Details

The route challenged drivers with a mix of wide, fast roads and twisty, rock-lined mountain passes:

  • Traslasierra Valley: Loose gravel and deep ruts tested tire wear and car stability at high speeds.
  • Pampa de Achala: High-altitude roads with thin air, fog, and technical sequences requiring perfect pacenotes.
  • Río Los Reartes: Multiple water crossings and rocky splash zones punished suspension setups and wheel alignment.

Cool, dry weather helped reduce mechanical failures, but the rough road conditions still took a toll on many leading entries. Trelles’ smooth, error-free pace stood out in contrast.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Gustavo Trelles & Jorge del Buono (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

2nd Place: Jorge Recalde & Martin Christie (Ford Escort RS Cosworth)

3rd Place: Armin Schwarz & Nicky Grist (Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD)

Trelles’ win marked a rare South American triumph on home soil—his pace may not have been the fastest, but his strategy and composure delivered a famous victory.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Aging but still resilient—its robust build and proven suspension helped it survive rough stages where newer cars faltered.
  • Ford Escort RS Cosworth: Quick and nimble—Recalde drove with passion, nearly matching Trelles but lost ground in rockier sections.
  • Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD: Powerful and smooth—Schwarz stayed in contention but couldn’t maintain top speed through technical stretches.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Altitude Effects: Engine power loss and reduced braking performance at high elevation challenged even the best-prepped cars.
  • River Crossings: Timing through water stages was critical—drivers risked damage or drowning engines without care.
  • Road Degradation: Repeated passes through stages left deep ruts and exposed rocks—car preservation became the key to success.

The 1993 Rally Argentina proved that consistency can beat raw speed—Gustavo Trelles delivered a tactically brilliant win that remains one of South America’s proudest WRC moments.

title: 1993 Rally New Zealand (New Zealand)
bio: Colin McRae earned his second WRC victory in New Zealand with a fearless drive through the smooth, fast gravel stages, showcasing both his raw speed and Subaru’s rising form.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1993 Rally New Zealand (New Zealand)

Date: August 5–8, 1993

Start Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Finish Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Total Distance: 396.00 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

The 1993 Rally New Zealand was a high-speed ballet through the lush forest roads of the North Island. Known for its flowing corners and cambered gravel, the event rewarded brave, committed driving. Colin McRae and Derek Ringer were in peak form, piloting the Subaru Legacy RS to its final WRC win before the debut of the Impreza. McRae’s fearless approach and growing maturity delivered an emphatic performance, putting Subaru in the spotlight and solidifying his reputation as a future champion.

🗺️ Route Details

New Zealand’s gravel roads offered perfect rally conditions—fast, grippy, and rhythmically challenging:

  • Whangarei and Kaipara Regions: Long, sweeping corners and wide forest roads with cambered surfaces that encouraged high-speed commitment.
  • Rotorua Loops: Damp forest floors with changing grip—stage knowledge and pacenote trust were critical.
  • Waikato Stages: Rolling terrain and smooth lines made for some of the season’s fastest average stage speeds.

Cool, dry weather made for consistent stage conditions—perfect for drivers who could hold a relentless rhythm and manage tire wear across long competitive legs.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Colin McRae & Derek Ringer (Subaru Legacy RS)

2nd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Lancia Delta HF Integrale)

3rd Place: Ari Vatanen & Bruno Berglund (Ford Escort RS Cosworth)

McRae’s fearless drive not only earned him the top step of the podium—it signaled Subaru’s readiness to compete at the highest level heading into the AWD Impreza era.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Subaru Legacy RS: A strong swan song—solid on fast gravel, stable in high-speed turns, and paired perfectly with McRae’s aggressive style.
  • Lancia Delta HF Integrale: Still competitive, especially in tighter sections—but beginning to lose ground on more modern chassis.
  • Ford Escort RS Cosworth: Fast and well-balanced—Vatanen pushed hard but couldn’t match McRae’s stage-winning pace.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Pace and Flow: Maintaining momentum through linked corners was essential—McRae’s smooth aggression set the benchmark.
  • Pacenote Accuracy: Fast blind crests demanded full trust between driver and co-driver—Ringer’s precision was flawless.
  • Tire Preservation: Though surface grip was high, long stages tested compound durability—Subaru struck the right balance.

The 1993 Rally New Zealand was a decisive moment for Colin McRae and Subaru alike—flawless teamwork, blistering speed, and rallying audacity delivered a memorable victory.

title: 1993 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)
bio: Juha Kankkunen thrilled his home crowd with a high-speed masterclass through the iconic Finnish forests, claiming a dominant win in the Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1993 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)

Date: August 27–29, 1993

Start Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Finish Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Total Distance: 482.00 km of special stages

Surface: Gravel

Renowned for its blinding speed and massive jumps, the 1000 Lakes Rally is one of the crown jewels of rallying. In 1993, local hero Juha Kankkunen, partnered with co-driver Nicky Grist, stormed through the stages to a resounding victory. Piloting the Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD, Kankkunen combined bravery, accuracy, and home soil knowledge to dominate on the flowing gravel roads of central Finland.

🗺️ Route Details

The Finnish stages were characterized by ultra-fast straights, rhythmic crests, and precision cornering through dense forests:

  • Ouninpohja: Legendary for its undulating jumps and blind corners—precision and courage were critical.
  • Laukaa and Ruuhimäki: Wide gravel sweepers and long straights with abrupt crests tested throttle control and car balance.
  • Lankamaa and Urria: Natural flow through forested trails, requiring tight synchronization between driver and co-driver.

Clear skies and dry conditions made the roads fast but unforgiving—one mistake at these speeds often ended a rally. Kankkunen’s calm aggression set him apart from start to finish.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Juha Kankkunen & Nicky Grist (Toyota Celica Turbo 4WD)

2nd Place: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Ford Escort RS Cosworth)
