The 1999 Safari Rally was not only a brutal test of machinery but a legendary performance from McRae. With one of the most iconic debut wins in WRC history, the Ford Focus WRC arrived on the global stage in spectacular fashion.

title: 1999 Rallye de Portugal (Portugal)
bio: Didier Auriol mastered the slippery gravel roads of Portugal to deliver a well-executed win in the Toyota Corolla WRC, navigating shifting surfaces and tough competition with trademark consistency.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1999 Rallye de Portugal (Portugal)

Date: March 21–24, 1999

Start Location: Figueira da Foz, Portugal

Finish Location: Figueira da Foz, Portugal

Total Distance: ~1,435 km (full route)

Competitive Stages: 385.76 km

Surface: Gravel

The 1999 Rallye de Portugal challenged drivers with its classic blend of abrasive gravel, slick corners, and unpredictable weather. Didier Auriol, known for his precise pace and strategic tire management, guided his Toyota Corolla WRC to a clean and calculated victory. With competitors falling victim to punctures, slippery ruts, and changing grip levels, Auriol’s veteran experience shone through across the rugged Portuguese countryside.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally took place in the central and northern regions of Portugal, using a variety of stage profiles and surfaces. Key sections included:

  • Arganil: Long, technical gravel with narrow tracks and notorious for fog and tire wear.
  • Lousã: High-speed hardpack with slippery patches and exposed rock, requiring perfect lines.
  • Mortágua: Flowing rhythm stages where balance and traction setup were critical.

As rain rolled through various stages, conditions alternated rapidly between grippy and treacherously slick, catching many drivers off guard and influencing tire strategy throughout the rally.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Didier Auriol & Denis Giraudet (Toyota Corolla WRC)

2nd Place: Tommi Mäkinen & Risto Mannisenmäki (Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI)

3rd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Repo (Subaru Impreza WRC99)

Auriol’s calm and steady approach allowed him to build and defend a lead while others faltered in the changing surface conditions, securing a vital win for Toyota early in the 1999 season.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Toyota Corolla WRC: Nimble and reliable on loose surfaces, the Corolla’s suspension performance and predictability gave Auriol the confidence to push when needed.
  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Strong in fast sections but suffered tire wear issues under prolonged aggressive use on Portugal’s abrasive roads.
  • Subaru Impreza WRC99: A consistent performer throughout, though slightly less sharp in tighter, rut-filled sections compared to the Corolla.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Grip Variation: Stages alternated between damp forest paths and dry dusty climbs, often within the same loop — making tire compound choice crucial.
  • Visibility: Fog in Arganil and rain-soaked windows reduced visibility in key early-morning runs, amplifying co-driver importance.
  • Car Preservation: Drivers had to balance speed with caution, avoiding sharp rocks and ruts that cost many crews valuable time or retirement.

The 1999 Rallye de Portugal was a rally of survival, strategy, and steady nerves. Didier Auriol’s textbook performance secured a second win for Toyota that season and kept his title challenge alive heading into spring.

title: 1999 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (Corsica)
bio: Philippe Bugalski stunned the WRC field by winning the 1999 Tour de Corse in a front-wheel-drive Citroën Xsara Kit Car, using precision and confidence on tarmac to outpace the top 4WD factory entries.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1999 Tour de Corse – Rallye de France (Corsica)

Date: May 7–9, 1999

Start Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Finish Location: Ajaccio, Corsica

Total Distance: ~1,027 km (full route)

Competitive Stages: 397.36 km

Surface: Asphalt

The 1999 Tour de Corse delivered one of the most surprising and historic results in modern WRC history. Philippe Bugalski, driving a front-wheel-drive Citroën Xsara Kit Car, outpaced the world's top four-wheel-drive machines on Corsica’s endlessly twisting tarmac roads. With perfect weather and optimal road conditions, the lighter, nimbler Xsara proved unbeatable in the hands of Bugalski, marking Citroën’s breakthrough WRC victory and shaking up expectations on what kind of car could win on pure asphalt.

🗺️ Route Details

Corsica’s rally stages are legendary for their relentless sequence of corners, steep cliffs, and minimal runoff. Key tests included:

  • Vico–Sagone: Long mountain descent with constantly changing corner radius and heavy brake usage.
  • Zérubia–Petreto: Tight switchbacks with technical climbs requiring impeccable rhythm.
  • Col de Sorba: High-elevation mountain pass that tested lateral grip and driver patience through endless turns.

The dry spring conditions meant the roads were clean and fast, giving 2WD cars like the Xsara a rare advantage over their heavier AWD rivals.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Philippe Bugalski & Jean-Paul Chiaroni (Citroën Xsara Kit Car)

2nd Place: Didier Auriol & Denis Giraudet (Toyota Corolla WRC)

3rd Place: François Delecour & Daniel Grataloup (Peugeot 206 WRC)

Bugalski’s victory marked the first modern-era WRC win for a front-wheel-drive car, while Auriol and Delecour gave chase but couldn’t match the Xsara’s agility on twisty Corsican tarmac.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën Xsara Kit Car: Ultra-light and nimble, with a sequential gearbox and aggressive asphalt setup — ideal for tight mountain roads and dry conditions.
  • Toyota Corolla WRC: Smooth and consistent, but hampered by extra weight in the tightest sections compared to the Xsara.
  • Peugeot 206 WRC: In its debut WRC season, showed impressive pace and agility but lacked the refinement of the Xsara on this occasion.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Endless Cornering: With virtually no straights, co-driver timing and rhythm were essential to carrying speed and avoiding mistakes.
  • Brake Management: The tarmac’s grip encouraged late braking, but disc temperatures needed constant attention on long descents.
  • Precision Driving: Corsica punished oversteer or understeer severely — the Xsara’s handling allowed Bugalski to stay clean and fast under pressure.

The 1999 Tour de Corse will be remembered as a turning point — not just for Citroën, but for the perception of what kinds of cars could win in the WRC. Bugalski’s drive was an instant classic, and a sign of things to come for the French manufacturer.

title: 1999 Rallye Catalunya – Rallye de España (Spain)
bio: Philippe Bugalski stunned the WRC field again with a second consecutive win in the front-wheel-drive Citroën Xsara Kit Car, dominating the smooth tarmac stages of Catalunya with clinical precision.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1999 Rallye Catalunya – Rallye de España (Spain)

Date: April 18–21, 1999

Start Location: Lloret de Mar, Spain

Finish Location: Lloret de Mar, Spain

Total Distance: ~1,145 km (full route)

Competitive Stages: 381.03 km

Surface: Asphalt

Just weeks after his breakthrough win in Corsica, Philippe Bugalski delivered another shock victory at Rallye Catalunya. Exploiting the ideal asphalt conditions and the lightweight handling of the Citroën Xsara Kit Car, Bugalski dominated more powerful 4WD rivals once again. His performance silenced critics and confirmed the Xsara's place as a tarmac weapon in the WRC arsenal — and proved Citroën was no longer just a guest in the WRC paddock.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally wound through Catalonia’s coastal mountains and smooth inland tarmac roads. Key stages included:

  • El Montmell: Fast and flowing asphalt with sweeping corners that rewarded rhythm and courage.
  • La Trona: Tight and technical stage with rapid transitions between second and fourth gear bends.
  • Querol: Elevation changes and braking zones challenged even the best setups for asphalt precision.

Dry weather and clean surfaces gave the front-wheel-drive Xsara ideal conditions to shine, with Bugalski setting blistering stage times against WRC machinery.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Philippe Bugalski & Jean-Paul Chiaroni (Citroën Xsara Kit Car)

2nd Place: Didier Auriol & Denis Giraudet (Toyota Corolla WRC)

3rd Place: Jesús Puras & Marc Martí (Citroën Xsara Kit Car)

Bugalski’s back-to-back win solidified Citroën’s rising power in asphalt rallying, while teammate Puras added to the celebration with a third-place finish — giving Citroën two podium spots in a field of 4WD heavyweights.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën Xsara Kit Car: Once again proved unbeatable on tarmac, combining a high-revving engine, sequential gearbox, and featherweight agility.
  • Toyota Corolla WRC: Smooth and dependable, but hampered by additional weight and slower turn-in compared to the Kit Car.
  • Subaru Impreza WRC99: Competitive in the fast sections but lacked the Xsara’s grip and responsiveness in tighter corners.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Asphalt Rhythm: Fast sweepers and long braking zones rewarded precision, consistent pace notes, and mechanical confidence.
  • Heat and Tire Wear: Warm spring weather pushed tire temperatures to the limit, especially for heavier AWD cars.
  • Driver Restraint: Maintaining consistent momentum without overdriving was key to managing the clean tarmac without mistakes.

The 1999 Rallye Catalunya confirmed Philippe Bugalski as a master of asphalt and the Citroën Xsara Kit Car as a true giant-slayer. It was a symbolic passing of the torch — and a warning to WRC teams of Citroën’s rising dominance to come.

title: 1999 Rally Argentina (Argentina)
bio: Didier Auriol powered to victory through the rough, high-altitude stages of Rally Argentina, securing a vital gravel win for Toyota and proving his versatility beyond asphalt.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1999 Rally Argentina (Argentina)

Date: May 8–11, 1999

Start Location: Villa Carlos Paz, Argentina

Finish Location: Villa Carlos Paz, Argentina

Total Distance: ~1,210 km (full route)

Competitive Stages: 378.00 km

Surface: Gravel

The 1999 Rally Argentina brought classic South American rallying drama: water crossings, altitude shifts, and brutal rocky tracks. Didier Auriol, better known for his prowess on asphalt, drove flawlessly across the demanding gravel roads of Córdoba province to claim an unexpected but well-earned win in the Toyota Corolla WRC. His victory came through a mix of pace, preservation, and perfect tire choices in the unpredictable conditions.

🗺️ Route Details

The stages were based around Villa Carlos Paz, featuring a variety of rugged and narrow tracks through mountain ranges and valleys. Key sections included:

  • El Condor–Copina: High-altitude rough roads with fog, low grip, and extreme tire wear.
  • Santa Rosa–San Agustín: Fast gravel tracks punctuated by deep fords and rocky straights.
  • Mina Clavero: Narrow, twisting mountain routes with steep drops and sudden surface changes.

The stages pushed suspension and tire durability to their limits, with many crews retiring due to mechanical failures or punctures in the abrasive terrain.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Didier Auriol & Denis Giraudet (Toyota Corolla WRC)

2nd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza WRC99)

3rd Place: Tommi Mäkinen & Risto Mannisenmäki (Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI)

Auriol’s steady hand and tactical driving gave Toyota another valuable win, while Burns and Mäkinen both suffered from minor setbacks that allowed Auriol to control the lead in the final stages.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Toyota Corolla WRC: Rugged and responsive, it handled rocky conditions well and showed surprising speed under Auriol’s clean driving style.
  • Subaru Impreza WRC99: Strong performance from Burns, but slight engine concerns and cautious water crossings cost crucial seconds.
  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Fast as always, but tire degradation and brake fade on longer stages made it harder to maintain a consistent pace.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Water Crossings: Several deep fords risked engine damage and required precise throttle control to avoid flooding.
  • Altitude Changes: Thin air in mountain stages reduced engine power and affected handling dynamics.
  • Rough Terrain: Rocks, dips, and washouts punished aggressive setups and caught out many top drivers with punctures or suspension damage.

Auriol’s win in Argentina was one of the most complete performances of his later WRC career — clean, clever, and composed — earning Toyota a critical boost in both championships.

title: 1999 Rally New Zealand (New Zealand)
bio: Tommi Mäkinen claimed a textbook win on New Zealand’s smooth and flowing gravel roads, using his Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI’s balance and speed to dominate one of the WRC’s most technical events.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1999 Rally New Zealand (New Zealand)

Date: July 16–18, 1999

Start Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Finish Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Total Distance: ~1,375 km (full route)

Competitive Stages: 358.00 km

Surface: Gravel

Renowned for its ultra-fast, cambered gravel roads and flowing rhythm, the 1999 Rally New Zealand delivered high-speed thrills and a triumphant performance from Tommi Mäkinen. Driving with controlled aggression and near-flawless precision, Mäkinen and his co-driver Risto Mannisenmäki secured a crucial victory for Mitsubishi in the championship hunt — a win built on mastery of the terrain and confidence in the Evo VI’s finely tuned handling.

🗺️ Route Details

Held on the North Island’s sweeping forest roads, the rally was defined by fast curves and a unique gravel surface with excellent grip. Notable stages included:

  • Te Akau South: Fast, flowing, and scenic — ideal for confidence-driving and maximum throttle commitment.
  • Possum’s Stage: A technical challenge named in honor of New Zealand rally icon Possum Bourne, with blind crests and deceptive braking points.
  • Whaanga Coast: Cliffside routes with stunning ocean views, loose gravel, and tight timing between corners.

Unlike many gravel rallies, New Zealand’s roads offered high speeds with fewer car-breaking hazards — rewarding drivers who could maintain momentum and take risks through the sweeping terrain.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Tommi Mäkinen & Risto Mannisenmäki (Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI)

2nd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza WRC99)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Corolla WRC)

Mäkinen’s experience and precision in high-speed gravel conditions allowed him to edge out Burns in a rally-long duel, while Sainz delivered another consistent podium for Toyota.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Stable and responsive on flowing roads; its suspension setup allowed for high-speed precision without sacrificing grip in cambered corners.
  • Subaru Impreza WRC99: Burns pushed hard all weekend, but struggled slightly with mid-corner balance in rougher sections.
  • Toyota Corolla WRC: Smooth and effective, especially under braking — but lacked the straight-line acceleration of the Evo VI on New Zealand’s wide-open sections.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Corner Commitment: Blind crests and long corner sequences demanded total trust in pacenotes — hesitation cost seconds.
  • Tire Selection: With high average speeds and cool weather, selecting the right tire compound for morning and afternoon loops was essential.
  • Momentum Management: The fast flow of stages made rhythm more important than raw power — one mistake could ruin a full split.

The 1999 Rally New Zealand was a reminder of why Tommi Mäkinen was a gravel master. With cool precision and unmatched pace, he delivered another benchmark performance and tightened his grip on the championship lead.

title: 1999 Rally Finland – 1000 Lakes (Finland)
bio: Tommi Mäkinen thrilled his home crowd with another dominant performance through the high-speed jumps and crests of Finland, securing a critical victory in his push for a fourth WRC title.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1999 Rally Finland – 1000 Lakes (Finland)

Date: August 20–22, 1999

Start Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Finish Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Total Distance: ~1,365 km (full route)

Competitive Stages: 344.68 km

Surface: Gravel

Rally Finland, famed for its extreme speeds and airborne crests, lived up to its legendary status in 1999. Tommi Mäkinen delivered a spectacular and surgical drive through his home stages, using every ounce of experience and car control to beat a stacked field. His Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI flew through the forests with perfect balance and aggression, giving Mäkinen another vital win in his championship campaign.

🗺️ Route Details

Set in the dense Finnish forests, the rally featured long straights, rhythm-based corners, and hundreds of jumps. Key stages included:

  • Ouninpohja: The most iconic stage in WRC, combining relentless crests with sweeping corners that test bravery and balance.
  • Lankamaa: High-speed curves with fast transitions requiring perfect throttle control and corner memory.
  • Ruuhimäki: Short, fast stage with spectacular final jumps and a fan-favorite finish.

Finland’s smooth gravel and fast flow allowed cars to reach some of the highest average speeds in rallying — but also punished hesitation or errors with immediate time loss or off-road consequences.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Tommi Mäkinen & Risto Mannisenmäki (Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI)

2nd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Repo (Subaru Impreza WRC99)

3rd Place: Freddy Loix & Sven Smeets (Mitsubishi Carisma GT Evo VI)

Mäkinen’s commitment and pace were unmatched, with Kankkunen delivering a nostalgic home podium, while Loix impressed with his control and speed in one of the most demanding rallies of the season.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Showcased supreme handling through jumps and crests with finely tuned suspension and aerodynamic balance.
  • Subaru Impreza WRC99: Kankkunen used his deep experience to maximize the car’s strengths, especially on long, fast corners.
  • Mitsubishi Carisma GT Evo VI: Loix proved the platform’s consistency and traction, earning a well-deserved podium among WRC veterans.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Jump Accuracy: Misjudging a crest could destroy rhythm or cause suspension damage — co-driver precision was everything.
  • Pace Commitment: Finland punished braking and lift-offs — corners had to be attacked blind and flat.
  • High Average Speeds: Maintaining consistent control at over 120 km/h across forests required total confidence and rhythm.

The 1999 Rally Finland was a celebration of speed, courage, and control — and Tommi Mäkinen’s victory further cemented his reputation as one of the greatest gravel drivers of all time.

title: 1999 Rally China (China)
bio: Didier Auriol conquered treacherous conditions and heavy fog to win the 1999 Rally China, guiding his Toyota Corolla WRC to a measured and dominant victory in one of the most demanding gravel rallies of the season.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1999 Rally China (China)

Date: September 17–19, 1999

Start Location: Shaoguan, Guangdong Province, China

Finish Location: Shaoguan, China

Total Distance: ~1,035 km (full route)

Competitive Stages: 387.96 km

Surface: Gravel

The 1999 Rally China returned to the WRC calendar with its signature mix of tricky gravel tracks, thick fog, and unpredictable weather. Didier Auriol took advantage of his clean and consistent driving style to dominate the event, claiming victory in conditions that caught many of his rivals off guard. The win reaffirmed Toyota’s competitiveness and Auriol’s reputation as one of the most adaptive drivers in the WRC field.

🗺️ Route Details

Staged in the misty and mountainous areas of Guangdong, the rally featured gravel surfaces with varying grip and visibility. Key stages included:

  • Beijiang Loop: Narrow and twisty forest tracks with limited runoff and sudden surface changes.
  • Xinfeng Gorge: A technical test with deep fog and loose gravel that required careful pacenote use and cautious throttle work.
  • Ruyuan Hills: Fast, flowing sections broken up by sharp corners and ruts — ideal for car control and timing discipline.

Rain and heavy morning fog made many of the stages treacherous, especially for those running further back in the start order. Tire choice and conservative setups proved key to success.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Didier Auriol & Denis Giraudet (Toyota Corolla WRC)

2nd Place: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Repo (Subaru Impreza WRC99)

3rd Place: Freddy Loix & Sven Smeets (Mitsubishi Carisma GT Evo VI)

Auriol’s composure and tire management gave him a decisive edge, while Kankkunen relied on experience to survive the fog, and Loix brought home another steady podium in unpredictable conditions.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Toyota Corolla WRC: Excelled in low-traction and damp conditions with balanced handling and precise cornering performance.
  • Subaru Impreza WRC99: Handled the mud and wet gravel with confidence, though struggled slightly with tire degradation on longer loops.
  • Mitsubishi Carisma GT Evo VI: Loix’s Evo VI delivered strong reliability and predictable turn-in through the technical stages.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Fog and Visibility: Multiple stages had sections with less than 10 meters visibility, requiring full trust in pacenotes and co-driver rhythm.
  • Surface Variation: From hard-packed clay to slick gravel, surface changes tested suspension tuning and line discipline.
  • Tire Strategy: Damp conditions and abrasive ruts made tire compound choice vital to maintaining grip without sacrificing endurance.

The 1999 Rally China was a test of control and calm under pressure. Didier Auriol’s flawless performance turned a chaotic and treacherous rally into a showcase of technical brilliance and veteran judgment.

title: 1999 Rallye Sanremo – Rallye d’Italia (Italy)
bio: Gilles Panizzi claimed his first WRC victory in commanding style at the 1999 Rallye Sanremo, mastering the tight Italian asphalt in the agile Peugeot 206 WRC and announcing himself as a future tarmac specialist.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1999 Rallye Sanremo – Rallye d’Italia (Italy)

Date: October 5–7, 1999

Start Location: Sanremo, Italy

Finish Location: Sanremo, Italy

Total Distance: ~1,080 km (full route)

Competitive Stages: 344.00 km

Surface: Asphalt

The 1999 Rallye Sanremo marked a breakout moment for Peugeot and Gilles Panizzi, as the French tarmac ace delivered a stunning performance to take his maiden WRC win. With Sanremo's twisty mountain roads suiting the compact and responsive Peugeot 206 WRC, Panizzi dominated from the outset, proving both his potential and the car’s competitiveness on sealed surfaces. It was a perfect synergy of driver, car, and terrain.

🗺️ Route Details

Sanremo’s stages climbed through the Ligurian hills, with a blend of narrow mountain passes, long tarmac descents, and rhythm-based switchbacks. Key stages included:

  • Colle d’Oggia: A technical climb with tight hairpins, minimal runoff, and ever-changing grip.
  • Monte Ceppo: Fast and narrow with elevation shifts and tight sequences — ideal for lightweight cars.
  • Bajardo–San Romolo: A classic Sanremo descent with flowing pace and tire management demands across corners of varying radius.

Warm and dry weather allowed Panizzi to fully exploit the tarmac capabilities of the Peugeot 206 WRC, while rivals struggled to match his consistency and pace through the long mountain stages.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Gilles Panizzi & Hervé Panizzi (Peugeot 206 WRC)

2nd Place: Didier Auriol & Denis Giraudet (Toyota Corolla WRC)

3rd Place: Jesús Puras & Marc Martí (Citroën Xsara Kit Car)

Panizzi’s win was a flawless execution of tarmac driving. Auriol’s experience kept him close, while Puras once again demonstrated the Xsara Kit Car’s pace despite its 2WD limitations.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 206 WRC: Agile and lightweight, the new 206 WRC thrived on Sanremo’s twisty roads — excelling in rotation and braking stability.
  • Toyota Corolla WRC: A consistent performer with strong corner exit traction but lacked the sharp response of the 206 in tight sequences.
  • Citroën Xsara Kit Car: Blistering on pure asphalt but limited by front-wheel-drive traction in uphill segments and tighter corners.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Technical Complexity: Constant steering input and precise co-driver calls were needed through hairpins, blind corners, and narrow sections.
  • Tire Management: Heat buildup and surface abrasion made correct compound choice and smooth driving essential across multiple loops.
  • Driver Focus: Minimal margin for error on the cliffside routes demanded maximum concentration and flawless braking discipline.

The 1999 Rallye Sanremo was a landmark win for both Peugeot and Panizzi. It marked the arrival of a new tarmac threat in the WRC and introduced fans to one of the sport’s most skilled asphalt specialists.

title: 1999 Rally Australia (Australia)
bio: Richard Burns delivered a flawless performance in the forests around Perth to win the 1999 Rally Australia, showcasing the Subaru Impreza WRC99’s precision and grip on the region’s slippery gravel roads.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1999 Rally Australia (Australia)

Date: September 3–5, 1999

Start Location: Perth, Australia

Finish Location: Perth, Australia

Total Distance: ~1,335 km (full route)

Competitive Stages: 386.00 km

Surface: Gravel

The 1999 Rally Australia delivered fast-paced gravel action on the ball-bearing roads of Western Australia. Richard Burns, driving the Subaru Impreza WRC99, handled the treacherous surface with total control to take a critical victory. The British driver’s measured aggression and smart tire strategy proved decisive, giving Subaru a key win and keeping the championship momentum alive.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally featured a mix of narrow forestry tracks and wider flowing roads, often lined tightly with trees. Notable stages included:

  • Helena South: Fast, tree-lined gravel with low grip and cambered corners that tested commitment and line precision.
  • Beraking: Long and flowing, with deceptive braking zones and surface variation from smooth gravel to hardpack.
  • Langley Park Super Special: A fan-friendly city-center stage in downtown Perth providing a unique contrast to the forest roads.

The loose surface of Rally Australia’s roads demanded careful tire selection and clean driving lines — mistakes were punished by loss of traction and time in the deep marbles.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza WRC99)

2nd Place: Tommi Mäkinen & Risto Mannisenmäki (Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI)

3rd Place: Carlos Sainz & Luis Moya (Toyota Corolla WRC)

Burns’s victory was built on surgical precision through the forests and a well-managed car setup. Mäkinen stayed close but couldn’t find the extra pace needed to challenge for the win, while Sainz delivered another consistent performance for Toyota.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Subaru Impreza WRC99: Stable and agile with excellent traction on Australia’s loose surface. Burns used its characteristics perfectly through tight corners and fast sweepers.
  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo VI: Strong performer but slightly unsettled in the slipperiest sections where Burns’s Subaru had the advantage.
  • Toyota Corolla WRC: Durable and reliable with good braking stability, but lacked the razor-sharp rotation of the Subaru in tight transitions.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Loose Gravel: The infamous ball-bearing surface made grip unpredictable and demanded exact car placement on the cleaner racing line.
  • Tight Margins: Tree-lined stages left no room for error — one missed braking point often meant retirement.
  • Heat and Dust: Australian spring weather dried out stages quickly, creating heavy dust clouds that hindered visibility for following cars.

Burns’s win in Australia was a defining moment in the 1999 season, proving his championship credentials and giving Subaru vital momentum heading into the season’s final rounds.

title: 1999 Network Q Rally of Great Britain (UK)
bio: Juha Kankkunen rolled back the years with a sensational victory at the 1999 Rally GB, mastering the muddy Welsh stages in his Subaru Impreza WRC99 and reminding the world why he was a four-time world champion.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 1999 Network Q Rally of Great Britain (UK)

Date: November 21–23, 1999

Start Location: Cheltenham, England

Finish Location: Cardiff, Wales

Total Distance: ~1,430 km (full route)

Competitive Stages: 380.00 km

Surface: Gravel (wet/mud)

The final round of the 1999 WRC season took place in the wet and wild Welsh forests of the UK. In slippery and misty conditions, rally legend Juha Kankkunen showed his mastery once again, securing his 23rd and final WRC victory. The event was a classic British mud-fest, with deep ruts, foggy mornings, and minimal margin for error — ideal for an experienced driver like Kankkunen to shine in his Subaru Impreza WRC99.

🗺️ Route Details

The event covered the iconic gravel stages of Wales, many of which have become legendary in rally folklore. Key stages included:

  • Hafren: Fast and flowing with slick corners and narrow forest lines, often run in thick fog.
  • Myherin: Open but muddy, requiring extreme car control through high-speed bends with poor visibility.
  • Sweet Lamb: Water splashes and jumps made this a fan-favorite, though treacherous at rally pace.

Welsh autumn conditions were brutal, with soaked gravel, mud-churned ruts, and leaves covering braking zones — making traction and visibility constant concerns.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Juha Kankkunen & Juha Repo (Subaru Impreza WRC99)

2nd Place: Richard Burns & Robert Reid (Subaru Impreza WRC99)

3rd Place: Freddy Loix & Sven Smeets (Mitsubishi Carisma GT Evo VI)

Kankkunen’s win was both a swan song and a masterclass, with teammate Burns right behind to secure a Subaru 1-2 finish. Loix rounded off the podium after a clean and steady drive in difficult conditions.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Subaru Impreza WRC99: Superb in slick conditions, with balanced power delivery and dependable grip — the car of the weekend in Welsh mud.
  • Mitsubishi Carisma GT Evo VI: Durable and composed but struggled for traction on the wettest sections compared to Subaru’s setup.
  • Toyota Corolla WRC: Competitive early on but suffered mechanical issues and couldn’t maintain pace to challenge the Subaru duo.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Mud & Visibility: Thick fog and muddy braking zones demanded precision from both driver and co-driver — even minor pacenote errors proved costly.
  • Tire Wear: Wet stages degraded quickly across multiple passes, forcing teams to manage compound performance throughout each loop.
  • Experience Factor: Veterans like Kankkunen thrived by avoiding mistakes and managing the car through unpredictable surface transitions.

The 1999 Rally GB was a poetic ending to the season — and to Kankkunen’s career as a WRC winner. With his final victory, he reminded the world why he remains one of the sport’s true legends.
